com.samskivert.util

Class Queue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.samskivert.util.Queue<T>

  • public class Queue<T>
extends Object
    A queue implementation that is more efficient than a wrapper around java.util.Vector. Allows adding and removing elements to/from the beginning, without the unneccessary System.arraycopy overhead of java.util.Vector.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Queue() 
      Queue(int suggestedSize) 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void append(T item)
      Appends the supplied item to the end of the queue, and notify a consumer if and only if the queue was previously empty.
      void appendLoud(T item)
      Appends an item to the queue and notify a listener regardless of how many items are on the queue.
      void appendSilent(T item)
      Appends an item to the queue without notifying anyone.
      void clear() 
      T get()
      Gets the next item from the queue, blocking until an item is added to the queue if the queue is empty at time of invocation.
      T get(long maxwait)
      Gets the next item from the queue blocking for no longer than maxwait milliseconds waiting for an item to be added to the queue if it is empty at the time of invocation.
      T getNonBlocking()
      Returns the next item on the queue or null if the queue is empty.
      boolean hasElements() 
      static <T> Queue<T> newQueue() 
      void prepend(T item) 
      int size() 
      String toString() 
      void waitForItem()
      Blocks the current thread waiting for an item to be added to the queue.

      • newQueue

        public static <T> Queue<T> newQueue()

      • clear

        public void clear()

      • hasElements

        public boolean hasElements()

      • size

        public int size()

      • prepend

        public void prepend(T item)

      • append

        public void append(T item)
        Appends the supplied item to the end of the queue, and notify a consumer if and only if the queue was previously empty.

      • appendSilent

        public void appendSilent(T item)
        Appends an item to the queue without notifying anyone. Useful for appending a bunch of items and then waking up the listener.

      • appendLoud

        public void appendLoud(T item)
        Appends an item to the queue and notify a listener regardless of how many items are on the queue. Use this for the last item you append to a queue in a batch via appendSilent because the regular append will think it doesn't need to notify anyone because the queue size isn't zero prior to this add. You should also use this method if you have mutiple consumers listening waiting on the queue, to guarantee that one will be woken for every element added.

      • getNonBlocking

        public T getNonBlocking()
        Returns the next item on the queue or null if the queue is empty. This method will not block waiting for an item to be added to the queue.

      • waitForItem

        public void waitForItem()
        Blocks the current thread waiting for an item to be added to the queue. If the queue is currently non-empty, this function will return immediately.

      • get

        public T get(long maxwait)
        Gets the next item from the queue blocking for no longer than maxwait milliseconds waiting for an item to be added to the queue if it is empty at the time of invocation.

      • get

        public T get()
        Gets the next item from the queue, blocking until an item is added to the queue if the queue is empty at time of invocation.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
